Award.AwardTitle: II-NEW: Collaborative Research: Robotic Catheterization Using Ionic Polymer-Metal Composite Actuator

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This research is motivated by the need for robust and intelligent clinical procedure of 'catheterization' which is widely used in medical communities. In this research, the fundamental framework to develop active catheters using an electro-active polymer called Ionic Polymer-Metal Composite (IPMC). The research work includes the design and fabrication methodologies of robotically controlled IPMC catheters as well as shape controls needed for use in complex passages. The research results will be disseminated in technical conferences and workshops as well as prototype demonstration. Knowing that the catheter based medical therapy/diagnosis is one of important medical technologies and all existing catheters in the market are based upon human operations, this active catheter technology will pave the way to a new biorobotic medical tool that can significantly contribute to improving quality of life.

Institution.Name: University of Nevada Las Vegas
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: BOARD OF REGENTS NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robotics has undergone dramatic changes during the past years especially in the fields of medical robotics applied for surgery, diagnostics, drug delivery, and rehabilitation. “Catheterization” is becoming one of the most important medical practices since it engages minimally invasive medical procedures to administrate diversified medical functions. The current catheter technology in clinical practices is mainly based upon manually driven “push/pull” mechanisms that are time-consuming and sometimes introduce high risks in damaging vessel and/or other internal parts of patients.  We successfully extended our knowledge about active catheter systems using an electroactive polymer system called Ionic Polymer-Metal Composite (IPMC).  The PI focused on modeling and control of the cylindrical IPMC for catheter applications.  The collaborator is Dr. Kwang J. Kim of University of Nevada, Las Vegas.  

Intellectual merit:  we have developed a physics based model encompassing electrostatics, charge transport phenomenon, and mechanics for IPMC and built a number of cylindrical tube type IPMC actuators that are useful for catheterization. Feedback control schemes have been developed to demonstrate feasibility of the tube type IPMC for catheterization.  

Broader impacts: Our development of a control model for time dependent end tip displacement of the tube type IPMC will likely to make a considerable impact on a robotic endoscope system for therapeutic and diagnostic reasons.  The robotic catheters can potentially play a pivotal role in the market for medical devices and surgical intervention.  Through this grant, we were able to contribute to build a unique research facility for motion controls for small robotic structures at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV).  This will extend UNLV’s unique research capability in microsystems and soft robots.

Modified by: Woosoon Yim
